commentBody:
I trust this will show up as an EASY Saturday; I can't be the only one -- or even one of a few -- who flew through this one. Oh, I enjoyed it -- thanks, Nick - but I renew my call to have Wednesday be a swing day, to include easy themelesses.

 -
Took a few passes to get a toehold, but I still finished it 10 minutes faster than my average.  Somehow chewy and easy at the same time, probably because the long answers came quickly to me.

Breezed through that one. Only thing that tripped me up was that I was a lot more "certain" that ARIADNE was wrong than I was that STELLaN was wrong. Didn't know anything called EMI, but aMI seemed right (America Music I...)
One of those puzzles where the first pass through you get barely anything, but then things start falling into place one by one...before you know it, you're done!  No frustrating bits.  Great puzzle.

This was just a nice puzzle full of fun entries and a lovely grid with only a few, but strategically placed black squares.  I got on a roll when I had enough crosses to recognize SANTAMONICAPIER and it‚Äôs ROLLERCOASTER. When I finished I was surprised to see I had finished quite a bit under my Saturday average.

A tip of the hat to Thomas Jefferson for bringing us VANILLAICECREAM

Pyroclastic Flows are deadly avalanches of volcanic ash that flow down the sides of volcanoes during an eruption. They can move over 60 miles an hour, destroying everything and everyone in their path. The eruption that destroyed Pompei was a pyroclastic flow. 

L
I know we all call it just PANERA, but doesn‚Äôt that caf√© deserve a marker for shortening, or at least informality?
Challenging, continually engaging and enjoyable.  When I started, I thought I was never going to get anything.  Then it slowly came together.  Very enjoyable!  Thank you!
Nice puzzle. I'm 71 and had a good laugh when I figured out the answer to 56 across.

Took a while to get really started but going over and over works. Loved the spanning entries. They were all well clued. Especially liked the clues for PEDIATRICIANS and NEANDERTHAL. Thanks, Nick for a great puzzle. Happy Saturday, y‚Äôall!

The instant I saw the clue for 12A I thought, PEDIATRICIANS, but then I thought, "Maybe pediatric-something, pediatricians is too short for such a long entry." Well glad I typed it in anyway because it turns out that some words are longer than they seem in my head.

I was totally on the same wavelength as the author today. One of my fastest Saturdays ever.
Sub-par  (near-record) time on - alas - a sub-sub-par puzzle. Meh
Either it is a Wed level or I am just a little smarter or luckier today than normal.

Given that I am a member of their sip club and my morning barista knows my order so well that when I ordered delivery this morning she wrote a note on the receipt stating that she‚Äôd made sure it was made the way I like it, I‚Äôm embarrassed it took me so long to get Panera.
I wanted the answer for "Evil spirits" to be ROTGUT

Once again, got the puzzle mostly put together, no big concerns...

...and then...

No music.

Looked everywhere, finally had to fall on the show-puzzle sword, only to find that the eye doctor is not SPELmaN, that a pyroclastic material isn't SmoG, that SALoMI is not the way salami is spelled in Milan, and that the Sex Pistols (could never stand any aspect of that group) were not hating on aMI.

I sure am blue.

"Hey, tree, is that a new coat? I'm lichen it!"

("Yeah, but it trunk in the wash.")

Congratulations on your debut, Nick!  A challenging, but fun puzzle for me. Loved that Santa Monica Pier was making its debut today, as well.  Many happy memories of summer nights there as a teenager in the 60‚Äôs.

Quite a lot of fun despite the fact that the top was a bundle of gimmes or near gimmes for me‚ÄîPEDITRICIAN because I am one, SNELLEN because I have used the chart, PANERA one of my favorite lunch spots and ARIADNE from one of my favorite myths, the plucky young lady who helped Theseus slay the MINOtaur from MINOS by giving him the yarn for the labyrinth but then getting jilted by him. The bottom was chewier for me, not the least because I had MICHIGAN before SUPERIOR, and I loved that stack at the bottom with the related clues and then the clever NEANDERTHAL. So, very enjoyable.
Every medical student is familiar with and has a pocket Snellen eye exam chart. It‚Äôs the one we‚Äôve all seen (literally) with the big ‚ÄúE‚Äù.

When I first opened it up tonight, I stared agape at the grid. It was so open looking and a bit intimidating to gaze upon. I don't know how to talk about grid design, but sometimes one just really hits me as lovely to look at. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Anyhow, another nice puzzle today! Very enjoyable! I went through this one (Saturday's) significantly faster than Friday's (today's), which was a good bit faster than my average Friday. Anyhow, so my Saturday solved way faster than my average Friday. Wow! Oh dear, I feel like I'm Steve Martin in The Jerk talking about how much time he and Bernadette Peters have been together! Har!! Lake SUPERIOR is a place of such joy and peace for my husband and me, so I enjoyed its inclusion today. It's so beautiful and raw!! It's also fun to think how I've been in both of the largest freshwater lakes in the world‚Äîboth by area and by volume. I'm a lucky lady!! Anyhow, though a bit fast, both puzzles I did today were a lot of fun to do though‚Äîand I now have more time to start binging Schitt's Creek again... A sad and way too soon ADIOS to the incomparable Catherine O'Hara. üíîüåπüíî A good Moira compilation, though I'd have added a fold in the cheese reference and Moira as a crow! https://youtu.be/75HX7RJCJ_8?si=aoC1SxvLXA4YHRSV

This crossword is one for the books! Congratulations to the one and only talented Nick Maritz on such a thrilling puzzle. Not only did I let out a number of hearty chuckles upon reading his witty puns, but I must also say that I enjoyed the debut of the iconic Santa Monica Pier in today's crossword -- my birthplace and favorite town to party it up in. In addition, as a partially Italian classical pianist, the references to music and Italian themes are stellar. I also love how the grid looks like the ferris wheel at the Santa Monica Pier, one of my favorite rides! Side note: Nick Maritz is really cute and also my boyfriend...
Nice hard puzzle for me, but doable because the spans are all fair. Can someone please explain how 50 across is car and not cat?
Tough and humbling. Good ego check.

Intimidating looking grid. 
Filled bottom up. 
Would have never gotten 52A so easily, except when I saw the clue 55A which referenced an attraction on 52A.  I filled in both immediately with no crosses. 

I love clues like 24A. ‚ÄúDeliberate‚Äù.  Don‚Äôt know what they are called.  But I‚Äôm not smart enough to figure them out immediately.  I was thinking ‚Äúthinking about something‚Äù

Good wordplay. 
Fair Saturday.  Maybe could been a Friday?  But it was a challenging fun solve. 

Thank you constructor.

The grid without the many long entries looked scary, and I felt dejected once I saw that several of them were trivia-based. However, while the first across pass yielded little, the down one was quite successful. It gave me enough crosses to get the spanners. I was finished in Wednesday time, and over two times quicker than yesterday, so either this was very easy for the day, or I suddenly became a genius - but we know the latter can't be true ü§™

It was an enjoyable solve though, if not quite what I expect of a Saturday, difficulty-wise.

Stabbed by the emus once again.  I always write comments directly in the box, and unless I happen to highlight and copy it before I move on, a comment is gone forever when their tender souls are offended.  The only possibility in this one is a word so mild it makes most of our crosswords look like Sunday school lessons, so it will probably eventually appear. Not deathless prose, but hey, I took the time to write an inoffensive comment. Maybe they could reprogram their A.I. to make it a little more accurate.
My fastest Saturday ever. Sometimes you feel you're channeling the puzzle constructor and things quickly fall into place. Of course, being an Angeleno didn't hurt when it came to SANTAMONICAPIER.

Quick and simple (to me, today).  The long fills weren't an issue, especially after baby docs.  I'm guessing this rates as "Easy"....  XWStats currently shows "Average".  Okay.

The upper right gave me the most trouble, but not much.  Not Howdy.  There has been a lot of slag in crosswords lately.

I know nothing about California but the bottom filled in without much issue.  I've heard of the pier somewhere, probably from Johnny Carson.

Yeah, I guess Average covers it.  :)
Great puzzle, and liked the fun fact about vanilla icecream. Congrats on the solid debut!

commentBody:
I'm afraid I'm still jonesing for another Weintraub fix, so any other clueing for me is going to seem dilute by comparison.

All well and good and fine Saturday fare over coffee with the cat snoring wheezily in the crook of my arm.

But no chills today.

Just twitchy after yesterday's hit.

No shade on Mr. Maritz.  Not a bit.

Superb photo spoiler today, by the way, Ms. Lovinger et al.

A puzzle about my neck of the woods? Yes please!! My niece had her 8th birthday party at the SANTA MONICA PIER! I think it was the best birthday party I‚Äôve ever attended. I‚Äôve mentioned that my husband works for UCLA Health. My kids have spent an inordinate amount of time at the Specialist PEDIATRICIANS at UCLA Santa Monica Hospital (specifically Orthopedics). Between my two youngest, they broke their wrists 8 times and my daughter‚Äôs foot three times in their chosen sports of snow boarding, lacrosse and Irish dance. We were on a first name basis with the entire staff ü§£ PEDIATRICIANS also made me want to say HOLLA to @SP, one of our resident constructors on our forum!! This puzzle was really speaking my language, so thank you, Nick and a hearty congratulations on your most excellent debut!
I wanted 18 across to be Yo Bro.

No complaints, but I found this relatively tough and did have to google some trivia to make headway, so beating my average didn‚Äôt really feel like a win. Also, I must still be recovering from a week of travels, because I spent too long staring blankly at lake SUPETIOR trying to figure out where the error was üòÖ

Now that I've had some time to get over yet another blue star, just *one* day after...

Start again...

I've had some time to think about how I behaved earlier when I couldn't get the gold star...

Naw, no one's going to believe that.

Despite my Biblical disappointment....this is really hard.

I blue this one (pun unintended), yet I felt blessed by a clue so perfect for me I couldn't believe it, about the largest freshwater Lake by surface area...I looked out my window and saw SUPERIOR.  Earlier in the day I heard some waves from it.

And I also have some fond feelings about the SANTA MONICA PIER (which is a whole other story).  

So, even being given two loooooong answers, I still couldn't get past that SmoG....let it go, let it go....

Breathe deeply and think of eels.

This was my first time playing a Saturday crossword (I‚Äôm a newbie). The wordplay was so fun! I remember getting 27-A even though entering it as an arbitrary guess and being shocked that I managed to enter the correct clue.

My fastest Saturday ever!! Yay me! 
PEDIATRICIANS was my ‚Äòin‚Äô (mentally having to remove the A, being a Brit), and it all seemed to roll on nicely from there ‚ò∫Ô∏è
I thought the lah-di-dah was a ‚Äòbit Wednesday‚Äô though‚Ä¶

The pier (of course) was a complete unknown, as was the roller coaster, and I love roller coasters. I've been on the 1914 wooden one in Copenhagen. I didn't know the eye chart had a special name, and I wore glasses  from age 14. You are all so knowledgeable! I thought at first the lake must be Baikal, but I found out it's only the oldest and deepest.

PANERA? Nope. The ice cream? Never. Peace out? (What?) 
I appreciate the wordplays (like CIDER) and still enjoyed it all.
One of my all-time favorites is the answer to [Old man}. I don't want to give it away in case anybody reading this hasn't yet done the puzzle.

Quick but enjoyable Saturday.  Learned today that PORTOFLONGBEACH has 15 letters as well.  Some fun cluing and not a ton of junk fill made for an excellent debut.  Well done!

5 debuts- 

BUILDSUP
MARTIALARTS
PEDIATRICIANS
SANTAMONICAPIER
SNELLEN
Great puzzle. Thank you!
Oh how fun!!! But this week Friday was more difficult than Saturday. Still enjoyed both.
The long ones were gettable either right off or with just a couple of crosses. Quick AND fun. Thanks.

Beauteous!  There were just enough toeholds to keep me motivated, with the rest being so fuzzy that I had to memory-dig, had to leave the brain alone to let the subconscious kick in, and had to make stabs and see what happens.

That is sweet work, punctuated by pings of delight.  I left the puzzle exuberant -- what a gift!

Memorable moments included dragging SNELLEN and CHIGNON out of my memory, as well as the flashes that came as I cracked each of the long answers.

I also loved the NYT-debut grid design with its photo album corners and dearth of scattershot black squares.

It's exciting to come across a new and talented Crosslandia voice on his debut, whetting my appetite for more.  This was, for me, a sweet, sweet Saturday, Nick.  Thank you!

I‚Äôm still relatively new to crosswords and have only been regularly completing Saturdays for a year or so now. I‚Äôm always amazed when a puzzle like this comes along where I think I‚Äôm absolutely NEVER going to get it, and then one corner gradually opens up and soon enough I find I‚Äôve finished the whole thing with a decent (for me) time - and, more importantly, thoroughly enjoyed the whole process. I‚Äôm completely in awe of the skill involved in this kind of construction!

A very tough puzzle for me. For the longest time I thought it would end up in failure. Who‚Äôd have thought that the opening of a pier would be a historical event.

Got there eventually. 

If you accept AEGIS then Paediatrician is misspelt üòÄ

Congratulations on a smashing debut, Nick!  What a beautiful open grid filled with fresh entries and clever cluing. I was fooled by 35D for a long time, as   beIGNet worked with the crosses, until ROLLERCOASTER set me straight!

A solid puzzle, rendered much too easy for a Saturday by so many overly direct clues. Solved without assistance in about 18 minutes, and I'm not a fast solver by any means.

Not a fan of this grid geometry---basically two half-puzzles one atop the other, with not much to bind them together. Prefer to have both long horizontals *and* long verticals in end-of-the-week puzzles.

Lots of the most common letters in this one, especially in the long entries, which (for me) greatly simplified the solving.

Congrats on the debut. Wish the editorial team had done more to offer Saturday-esque cluing.

commentBody:
In neuropsychology there is a phenomenon called "chasing losses."

It is what fuels gamblers' need to continue wagering in response to losing.

Losing increases secretion of all the relevant neurotransmitters which are implicated in the compulsion to recoup the losses - to end up...up.

Can it be that the emus' apparently random grazing and consumption, like so much cud, of perfectly innocent but time-and-energy-requiring comments is among this publication's tools to ensure we only redouble our efforts to be read here?

in some deep but safe sense...to be seen?

Truly a lovely, fun, sparkly debut.

Two thumbs up!

Stay warm all.
A really satisfying brain-tickling puzzle for a Saturday. It‚Äôs exciting to me, a longtime fan of the NYT crossword, to see new puzzle creators who bring the good stuff. Thank you!

Okay, I will admit it. Every time I see a new constructor, my heart drops. Here we go, I think, rap groups, current slang, recent movies, and Star Wars or Star Trek.

But not this debut. I guess when PEDIATRICIANS popped right into my head I though it would all be this easy. Not quite. But a nice amount of trivia made it a fun solve.

I got SNELLEN with just two letters; I know that's an answer that was always somewhere in my brain (along with the Brannock Device), and besides, I had to look at one at the beginning of the week for my deteriorating vision. Loved the way SANTAMONICAPIER played out after just a few letters, as well as ROLLERCOASTER. I did goto the pier once on a short trip to L.A., but just to have dinner in the mall across the street, so not actually a visit to the pier. 

All in all, a delightful puzzle that was just hard enough to make it a good solve, with some very nice, fresh answers.

Remember our mantra, y‚Äôall, bestowed upon us by our beloved St. Deb:  ‚ÄúYour mileage may vary.‚Äù

Regardless of whether we liked the construction (I did) or the clueing (I did), we really have to give props to anyone who can debut with a Saturday puzzle.  That‚Äôs a feat worth celebrating.  Well done, Mr. Maritz:  I thoroughly enjoyed your debut puzzle, and I hope to see you back for many more!

Poor Ariadne!

A girl from a family whose women habitually make poor romantic choices--her mother fell in love with a bull--she fell head over heels for the Athenian prince Theseus, who had come to Crete expressly to murder her brother-in-law, Asterion*. She helps him do so--that whole bit about the labyrinth and the spool of thread and all--and, afterwards, now being obviously persona non grata at Cnossos, fled with Theseus back to the mainland. 

On the way, they stop for a little R&R on the isle of Naxos, to picnic on the beach, eat a little vanilla ice cream, and ride the pier-side roller coaster there. All that excitement, and the crash from the sugar-buzz, makes Ariadne sleepy, and, waking from her nap, she discovers that Theseus has left without her. Was he as cad, or merely forgetful? Opinions vary. In any case, he later marries her sister, Phaedra.

Ariadne is justifiably distraught, and even considers suicide. Lucky for her, she receives some solace from one of the amusement park carnies, who offers her some refreshment stronger than sweet cider, and turns out to be none other than Dionysus, God of Wine, in disguise. So I guess not poor Ariadne after all . . .


*As I mentioned a couple days ago, Asterion, aka the Minotaur, has always seemed to me a tragic figure in the whole affair. Say their name.
Terrific Saturday challenge.

Whew. Nice puzzle but a good long workout for me. For once I'm actually surprised that so many others found it unusually easy. Quite a few things that I was NEVER going to get without some crosses - SANTAMONICAPIER, SNELLEN and some others. But.. I grew up in the UP so at least SUPERIOR was a gimme. No big deal. 

Unusually tough puzzle find today. I'll put that in a reply. 

...

First entry:  CIDER, since OLIVE OIL was too long.  
Then 50A had to be CAR or CAT, so I entered CA_ and moved on.
The Lord's Prayer gimme and the King Charles SPANIEL opened up the SE, and bestowed A PIER and the entire South filled in, with 54D answering the question about 50A.....

The whole puzzle was rather like that--remove one brick and the entire wall came down.
A long acquaintance with eye charts doesn't explain why I knew 11D, but that entry was helpful for HOLLA (really?) and SLAG (Srsly?) and EMI (who?)  I thought "pyroclastic" meant something like flammable...

The only big disappointment was 1A "Grappling is used in this," where I so, SO wanted it to be related to PIRACY on the HIGH SEAS.  
Maybe next time, Nick?  Congrats.
I made my way into this via the southeast corner and had the bottom half of the puzzle finished fairly quickly. Then once PEDIATRICIANS fell into place, it didn't take long.

Didn‚Äôt know any of the trivia but made slow progress and got a solid hour‚Äôs worth of engagement for my Saturday morning. Fun debut!

Do ultra-fast solvers feel like Saitama does in OPM? Constantly chasing stronger and stronger monsters to get the same challenge but never quite getting the satisfaction?

This one started as a major challenge, as it took me quite a while to get a toehold, and I solved it pretty much SE to NW. Was sure I‚Äôd have to surrender and look up quite a few but I managed to finish without any. Was also sure I‚Äôd be over my average time but was surprised, and delighted, to see I was actually 20% under my average. A pretty much perfect Saturday puzzle.

(This comment should be read with
a poor attempt at a British accent,
speaking down to the plebs who have gathered 
round to hear my wise words...)


For twelve delicious years, 
I owned an ice cream parlor with my husband.

A micro-creamery, if you will.

We made our own, 
and it was the most decadent
cream on the planet.

Ergo, I am obviously
an *expert* in all things ice cream-y.

That said, I can detect a true 
aficionado by what they ask to taste.

Vanilla.
Vanilla is the answer.

Pared down to its essence,
the cream will tell you its worth.

And, 
what it is not.


[CC backs away slowly until
finally disappearing into a mist]

Amazing puzzle! There was very little glue, and the fill was full of fun words: INCUBI, ARIADNE, LICHEN, AEGIS. I'm willing to forgive TAROS, but only because it's my favorite ICE CREAM flavor at the Grand Ole Creamery in Saint Paul.

With very little deference to Mr. Vonnegut, and fully aware he meant it semi-poetically: science is nothing like magic, and it never ‚Äòworks‚Äô in the sense implied.

Magic (of the wizard and fairy-tale varieties that we all wish was real, ‚Äòmagical thinking‚Äô) tries to accomplish things using made-up rules or guessing or trickery or mysterious innate powers. But it is anathema to science, to knowledge, to putting in the hard work of testing theories to find out how things go. And magic is particularly against math (except maybe counting how many times to turn around before you say ‚ÄòShazam‚Äô), and the statistical basis of science that ensures no ‚Äúscientific fact‚Äù is without uncertainty. Science doesn‚Äôt ‚Äòwork‚Äô. It *is* work - slogging to just explain in detail how things in the real world worked, this time we looked, at least.

Nature - that is where the magic is. Natural laws we have no clue about, really, where they come from and why. Atoms. Forces. Solid things made of mostly empty space. This is scary magic, that works. The closest humans come to ‚Äòmagic that works‚Äô is engineering - not science.

Rare day when I mostly see comments about the level of difficult, ones with which I'd usually agree. Instead I had a sub 10-minute solve and a new personal best. Instantly getting the first three across answers sure helped!
Quite impressed, Nick. What a debut. I look forward to many more.

Caitlin, I have regularly defended your choice of lead (or is it lede?) photo for Wordplay, which appears in the bottom left corner of the puzzle page, for those who solve on-line on a pc; but for anyone (not me) who might recognize the roller-coaster at Santa Monica Pier, today's photo is not one, but two, spoilers.

Quelle disappointment when that French¬†dessert didn't turn out to be something really exciting like a Bombe Glacee, a Coupe aux Marrons, a Profiterole or a Charlotte Russe.

OTOH, the first three can't be made without VANILLA ICE CREAM, so there's that.¬† And if the dessert itself isn't very interesting, the clue certainly is.

The clue for PEDIATRICIANS is clever-ish, but not clever enough, in that I saw it immediately and¬†it ushered me into the North section.¬† Puzzledom's favorite chess player TAL was another slam-dunk.¬† Otherwise the top section would have been much harder, since I was looking for a climbing sport or a wrestling sport at 1A.¬† And these days, with all the contemporary¬†slang, "Peace out" can be just about anything.

Somehow this seemed harder as I was solving than it seemed after I was through solving, if you see what I mean.¬† All things considered, it wasn't really that hard as Saturdays go.¬† But the stacks were lovely and I found the puzzle engrossing.

Well, that‚Äôs one for the You Have To Be An American file. Don‚Äôt get me wrong; it was fun and tricksy and just right for (another) wet Saturday, but of course I was completely stumped at 52A and 55A, not to mention 12D. Often when confronted by total unknown clue/answers I can generally pick my way through the crossing clues. Not today though. Ah well. I did manfully try to squeeze San Francisco and Golden Gate Bridge in there, so at least my geography is not completely awry?

Interesting to see SLAG get another outing so soon and TIL that VANILLA ICECREAM came from France. Bien sur, all delicious food comes from La Belle France.

I will never adjust to en pointe answering to ON TOE. My daughter‚Äôs ballet teacher would faint in horror at the term. Miss Bennett was not a woman to be crossed.

This grid showcases the art and science of making a Saturday puzzle.

It‚Äôs an uber-low word count grid (66), low black-square count (33), with hardly a hint of junk.  This isn‚Äôt simply done with a computer program; it‚Äôs a process marked by edits and choices, by erasing swaths and replacing them, then doing it again and again, until the box shines.

There are interesting and colorful answers woven in, beautifying the grid: INCUBI, BASS LINE, AEGIS, SCRAPES (as clued), SANTA MONICA PIER, CHIGNON, LICHEN, even SALAMI.  

Just making these things happen requires high skill ‚Äì there‚Äôs your science, with a generous helping of art.

The cluing is an art in itself.  There have to be enough toeholds to keep the solver motivated, but that must be balanced by riddles, vagueness, arcana, and misdirects to get the solver doing the luscious work of Solving.  If there are too many toeholds, the solver feels cheated, if there is too much toughness, the solver feels frustrated.

To find the sweet spot, the right balance, well, that‚Äôs an art.  No puzzle will please everyone, but a high-quality puzzle will please most.  That‚Äôs what I believe Nick made today, and to debut with this puzzle is remarkable.  IMO, high props are in order!

What a fine debut, Nick -- thank you for such an engaging grid! Just when I thought we knew everything we needed to know about Thomas Jefferson, TIL about the origins of VANILLA ICE CREAM. Like others, I was hoping it would have been a fancier French dessert. Mais non . . .

Happy Saturday, everyone -- stay safe & warm!

Great debut! I‚Äôm in awe of such creativity. SNELLEN SLAG HOLLA section took me some time at the end. Figured it must be EMI as it‚Äôs the only three letter British label I know. TIL SALAMI is Milanese.
According to a lab analysis, I have more Neanderthal DNA than most anyone. Yet, I was still able to finish this puzzle in good time.

The Sex Pistols were famously dropped by their record label after an appearance on a TV chat show, that descended into a profanity-laced donnybrook. To be fair, the presenter was totally winding them up right from the start. Anyway, every time EMI appears as an answer I sing that song to myself, and here it is in the clue! I think that's a first. "Hello EMI, goodbye."
As a pretty good, not great, solver I loved the puzzle and was proud of my almost perfect solve. Kudos to those who found the crossing of Snellen, slag and emi ‚Äúeasy‚Äù. Not me.
INCUBI.  Had no idea, asked my teenage son, he said INCUBI are nightmares in Italian (he is half Italian).  Thanks son!
Had to go to my trusty autocorrect about 50% through. I'm just not up to snuff on Saturdays' difficulty levels. But this one was still very fun. Loved minor injuries. Thank you, creator. Cheers.

Is there a word for the little Saturday morning fist pump and woo hoo that slips out when you land a clean solve on a puzzle you found rather difficult? The ‚Äúwoo hoo‚Äù that, even though it‚Äôs a quiet one, still startles your wife a bit and makes her face the day with the realization that she married a crossword nerd?

Hope she doesn‚Äôt tell the other baseball dads. Time for 10U tryouts.
Just came to say I did no word checks this Saturday. Also liked the puzzle done by a Pianist!
Nice one today.  No references to superhero movies, historic third basemen, or texting abbreviations.  More like this please.
Nice Saturday vocab clinic....  Perfect day to start from the bottom w Pater Noster. Excellent debut, Nick!
Must have been particulary fuzzy headed this morning as this one came together very slowly, and then all at once in a "bottoms up" solve.  A very fine debut.  Congratulations.
ADIEU and ADIOS are the same length! I struggled with that for most of an hour before I realized I had the wrong Romance language loanword.

We wimpy southerners are dealing with another wintry cold snap (scorm?) and forced to hunker down. I'm not partial to hunkering, sorry.
I'm assuming arr = arrangement in sheet music?

I wanted the Lord's Prayer solution to be padre. It was to my surprise was when it turned out to be in Latin, and not Italian and definitely not Espanich or Francias.

Here's what I didn't realize:
Pater Noster also historically refers to rosary beads, named after the prayer's opening. Not being Catholic, I had no idea, although rosary beads are not new to my vocab.

My wife worked in the Abrams Building in Frankfurt back in '88, or so. In between floors were devices called Paternosters, kind of intimidating looking contraptions. They're continuous loop elevators that one leaps on and off at will.

Here's what else I never knew:

The name Paternoster elevator is called as such because of its design of a loop, similar to rosary beads. Now I understand the name, as I remember calling on the Lord's name several times as it rounded the top floor for the descent. Similarly, while rounding the basement level for the ascent.

commentBody:
@Jonathan
I think it's luck, or that my memory (or sense of humor) is a little imparied; it took longer than usual to figure things out.

@Francis

First pass through and EMI was one of the only ones I knew.  Now that song is in my head.  Loved the Sex Pistols.

@Francis

There are some that everyone thinks are super easy and they were super hard for me...  It happens. Please don't be blue!  There's more than enough to be blue about as is! 

Those crosses were tricky for me too but I did feel confident about SALAMI and had good guesses on SLAG and EMI. They were my last fills and I wasn't confident. 

I also got a little caught up being overly thinking that papER for hot off the presses, so I had to unwind a little mess there. So even though most of it went fast for me, there were trickier little parts.

@HeathieJ

Well, to an extent the "blue" is for the color of star I got, and that I've been getting with some regularity lately.

@Francis

Ahhh! 

I've had a few lately too. Not the norm for me anymore. Lately, sometimes because I haven't cared to fly speck or just kind of it not engaging me enough. 

Remember, these days are anything but normal... and it can't help but mess with other areas like puzzling. I see that big time in myself. My brain goes between outrage, depression, overwhelmption (made up word in honor of Moira Rose), and fogginess...  The only thing that helps me is being able to talk about it and being able to take some actions. I can't get out on the streets right now, but I am blessed enough that I can give. Today I gave to an org that is helping with rent for those many folks having to hide and unable to work, and I signed a petition to put a moratorium on evictions right now. (Never really think petitions help, but who knows!) Yesterday, I gave to a local Spanish church that is coordinating safe food deliveries for the shut-in families in need. Those are the things I can do right now and it helps to do my part. 

That's why I'm glad today that both puzzles engaged me more and gave a bit of an additional reprieve that the last week or so of puzzles didn't do. 

Anyhow, a bit of a ramble, as usual, but I'm almost certain your cognition is just fine but that the madness is making it a bit tougher.

@Julio

I have to be honest; I probably didn't listen to the Sex Pistols enough to make any valid judgement at all.

It was more a time of when rock seemed to be moving to a place I didn't want to follow, and I think the Sex Pistols were one of the earlier bands to do so.

But, my taste in music isn't anything special, so whatever rocks your boat.

@Francis

It's fine as long as you don't think Coldplay is any good...

@Francis
I feel your pain. I, too, wonder about the signs of failing cognition. But I know that not a single doctor I go to in this physician-starved desert I call home would spend the time necessary to administer the MOCA test to me.

@Francis,

Like others have said here, I really don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs you. 

I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôm not the first to one to have a noticed a pattern to the comments.  The early ones are, naturally, made by folks who have finished the puzzle quickly and may have found it somewhat easy. Praise for the constructor(s). 

Then come the complaints: too hard, too obscure, unfair, canceling my subscription, yada yada yada.  

Followed by latecomers like myself, and  those who took their own sweet time diving, thoroughly enjoying their discoveries and learning experience and quite proud of doing a hard puzzle with few or no lookups. 

Kind of a sandwich if you will. 

You‚Äôre fine. ü´Ç

@Francis "Easy" = "I know it"; "hard" = "I don‚Äôt know it". 

Example clue: "Famous contrived Scrabble play that scores over 1700 points". Answer: OXYPHENBUTAZONE. Nobody but long-time tournament Scrabble players would know that bit of folklore, but those who do would remember it instantly.

@Francis aw, some days are like that. Snellen should have been a gimme for me considering the chart gets used many times a day in the pediatric clinic where I work! There's nowhere convenient to put it out of the way, so I wait until the kid is at the end of a line then say "sorry!" as I dart past. Waiting for the day when one of them says "j m o old woman r" lol.

I got hung up thinking the chef had to be Sue for sous chef and that caused a cascade of confusion!

@HeathieJ,

I‚Äôm so sorry that you‚Äôre having physical ailments. I‚Äôm sure you know that just that by itself is enough to make you feel despair, let alone all of the unimaginable things going on in your world.  

But when I read about what you‚Äôre doing, that gives *me* hope.  You and others like you are still reaching out and doing what they can to counter the evil actions taking place. And I have to believe that you will win the day. 

You are far from useless. ü§ó
